intro: Great job exploring Earth's rotation and revolution! Let's test your understanding with some fun questions.

questions.question: What causes day and night on Earth?
options: A) Earth moving around the Sun
B) Earth spinning on its axis
C) The Sun moving around Earth
questions.hint: Think about what happens when a spinning top turns - different sides face outward!

questions.question: Why do we have different seasons?
options: A) Earth gets closer and farther from the Sun
B) Earth's tilted axis points toward or away from the Sun
C) The Sun changes its temperature throughout the year
D) Clouds block the Sun more in winter
questions.hint: Remember the dancer leaning while walking around a spotlight!

questions.question: If it's summer in the Northern Hemisphere, what season is it in the Southern Hemisphere?
questions.hint: When one hemisphere tilts toward the Sun, what happens to the other hemisphere?

questions.question: How long does it take for Earth to complete one full rotation?
questions.hint: Think about how many hours are in one complete day and night cycle!

followups: Try creating a simple model at home using a flashlight as the Sun and a ball as Earth to see these concepts in action!
Explore how different planets in our solar system have different rotation periods and seasons.
summary: Earth spins on its axis every 24 hours, creating day and night. Earth also orbits the Sun once every year. Earth's axis is tilted at 23.5 degrees, which causes seasons - when one hemisphere tilts toward the Sun, it experiences summer while the opposite hemisphere has winter.
